thread.title: With Van Zeyl out, Argos have a massive hole to fill
thread.title_full: With Van Zeyl out, Argos have a massive hole to fill

title: With Van Zeyl out, Argos have a massive hole to fill
text:
Suddenly, but not entirely unexpectedly, the Argos must tackle the issue of somehow replacing Chris Van Zeyl, Toronto’s starting right tackle. 

Devastating is perhaps too harsh a word when describing the absence of a player of Van Zeyl’s ilk, but it clearly does not bode well for an Argos team coming off a short week for their game in Montreal on Thanksgiving Day Monday. 
The Als, despite their recent woes, are a good defensive team with the schemes and personnel to wreak havoc, a team that has beaten some high-end opponents by dominating the line of scrimmage. 
Without Van Zeyl, the Argos clearly are weakened, and the options to replace what is essentially an irreplaceable piece remain limited. 
The most obvious will feature Wayne Smith at right tackle, a Canadian replacing a Canadian starter. 
The Argos could go with an American, but it won’t involve Jarriel King, who is injured. 
Van Zeyl hurt his calf during Tuesday night’s win in Ottawa. 
“He’s going to be out a while,’’ said Argos head coach Scott Milanovich, who also has the option of starting Matt Sewell. 
Van Zeyl may be lost for three weeks, perhaps longer depending on how well he reacts to during his rehab. 
Continuity gets disrupted when a lineman goes down, depth comes into question and even the ratio will have to be revisited as the Argos play Montreal for the first time this season. 
“From a quarterback stand point, those guys (offensive tackles) are more on an island, particularly in our pass protection because we protect from the inside out,’’ added Milanovich. “We ask our tackles to stand up and block our guys one on one all the time.” 
Milanovich is a big fan of Van Zeyl and for good reason given how the Mac product plays and how resilient he is when adversity strikes. 
When Van Zeyl can’t play, you know it’s bad. 
“He’s athletic, big and strong,’’ said Milanovich of Van Zeyl, who played in his 100th CFL game a few weeks ago when the Argos visited Edmonton. 
“He knows the league. He’s comfort for us and for me as a coach. Losing him will be a big deal.” 
Milanovich also announced that all-purpose H-back Alexandre Dupuis hurt his foot late in Ottawa. 
“We’re trying to find the proper orthotics,’’ said Milanovich. “We’re hopeful (Dupuis can line up on Monday in his native Montreal). He’s not talked about much, but he’s had a big impact for us.” 
Dupuis is a true blocking back, but he’s got decent hands and has been used as a receiving option. 
He can also block and is used on the Argos’ jumbo packages. 
WHITAKER PUMPED TO FACE FORMER TEAM 
There’s no sense of sentimentality or nostalgia for Brandon Whitaker, the one-time Alouettes running back who returns to Montreal for the first time since his former club released him. 
For Whitaker, it’s all business, maintaining a business as usual approach as Monday’s big kickoff draws closer. 
“It’s a business trip,” said Whitaker. “It’s football. It’s part of the business. You might be on one team for a long time and you end up somewhere else. 
“Of course it’s going to be fun to be playing my guys, the guys I’ve played with, but we’ve got to get a win.” 
Given his time in Montreal, Whitaker is well aware of the Als’ defensive packages and blitzes. 
“They have a very good defence,’’ said Whitaker. “They’ve always had a very good defence. I know first hand of their blitzes and in that regard I do have a little bit of a jump. For us, we have to execute and do what we do.” 
BACK TO THE HAMMER 
The Argos made public the worst-kept secret in football on Thursday, a move to Hamilton to play home games given the return of post-season baseball to Toronto. 
It has been known for months that the nomadic franchise would be getting the boot from Rogers Centre, the only surprise being why nothing has been done to keep the Argos in town in some makeshift venue to provide a true homefield advantage. 
When David Braley gets involved, money rules the day and logic and doing what’s right for the football team goes by the wayside. 
It’s why Tuesday’s “home’’ game was moved to Ottawa. 
It’s why the Oct. 17 home game against Calgary will now shift to Tim Hortons Field and why the Oct. 23 game against Montreal will also be played in the Hammer. 
All told, that’s four home games not being staged in Toronto, beginning with the season opener played in Fort McMurray, where the game drew flies. 
It was supposed to be a time for the Argos to take aim on the playoffs, the team surviving a difficult road stretch to begin the season, but knowing the schedule was going to be home friendly with five of six, including the final four, at home. 
If anything, players and coaches have become numb to the stupidity. 
At least players receive a per diem.
